title: Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | SB 1.8.37 | 06-03-2022
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.key_quote: In this session we will be discussing from the 37th verse of the 8th chapter of the first canto of Srimad Bhagavatam continuing the prayers by Queen Kunti
segments.summary: The lecture begins with Sanskrit prayers and an introduction to the verse from Srimad Bhagavatam that will be discussed, focusing on Queen Kunti's prayers.

This segment explains that Kunti Devi's prayer highlights the pure devotee's complete dependence on Krishna for protection, contrasting this with the non-devotee's reliance on temporary and ultimately insufficient shelters.

segments.key_quote: What is the material disease? To be independent of Krishna.
segments.summary: The speaker defines the material disease as the desire to be independent of Krishna, emphasizing that our natural constitutional position is one of dependence on Him, which paradoxically leads to true independence from other material influences.

segments.key_quote: But a cruel material nature does not allow us to become independent.
segments.summary: This segment discusses the futility of trying to become independent of the laws of nature through material advancement, using the example of Ravana's attempt to build a staircase to heaven as an illustration of this misguided endeavor.

segments.key_quote: The highest goal of human civilization is to work hard under the guidance of the supreme lord Krishna and become completely dependent on him.
segments.summary: The speaker asserts that the highest achievement is to work diligently while remaining completely dependent on Krishna, citing the Pandavas as an example of this ideal, teaching others that complete dependence on Krishna ensures safety and security.

segments.key_quote: Pandavas are dependent on the goodwill of the supreme lord krishna does not mean that krishna will do everything i don't have to do anything no they are not idle parasites
segments.summary: This segment clarifies that dependence on Krishna does not imply passivity; the Pandavas were highly qualified and active, but they still recognized their constitutional dependence on the Lord's mercy.

segments.key_quote: The perfection of life is therefore to become dependent on the will of the Lord instead of becoming falsely independent in the material world
segments.summary: The speaker explains that the pursuit of false independence in the material world is an illusion, and true protection comes from becoming 'sanatha' - dependent on the will of the Lord, shielding us from the unfavorable conditions of material existence.

segments.key_quote: Therefore, directs us that after many, many births, one fortunate person becomes aware of the fact that Vasudeva or Krishna is all in all and that the best way of leading one's life is to surrender unto him completely.
segments.summary: This segment discusses how the deluding power of maya makes us forget the undesirable nature of material existence, emphasizing that only after many births does a fortunate person realize Krishna is everything and surrender to Him, becoming a Mahatma like the Pandavas.

segments.key_quote: The scriptures are teaching us that we should depend upon the Supreme Lord.
segments.summary: The lecture concludes by reiterating that the scriptures teach dependence on the Supreme Lord, exemplified by the Pandavas' relationship with Krishna, and highlighting Kunti's prayer expressing their complete reliance on Him.
